question: What must you use on a telescope to photograph solar flares and solar prominences?

content.source_1: Solar prominences and many flare structures are most conspicuous at the hydrogen-alpha spectral line (656.28 nm); in broadband “white-light” views these chromospheric features are generally invisible, especially at the limb.
content.source_2: Astrophotographers capture prominences by using a dedicated hydrogen‑alpha solar filter/etalon system on a telescope (sub-angstrom bandpass around 656 nm), which isolates chromospheric emission and reveals flares and prominences.
content.source_3: White‑light solar filters and Herschel wedges are designed for photospheric imaging (sunspots, granulation) and inherently do not reveal limb prominences or most flare structure.
content.source_4: The calcium II K line (≈393.4 nm) is another chromospheric diagnostic; with specialized Ca‑K filters, solar imagers record flare brightenings, plage, and—given sufficient aperture and sensitivity—prominences at the limb.
content.source_5: Many solar observatories produce daily Ca‑K filtergrams specifically to monitor chromospheric activity and flares, because Ca‑K isolates the chromosphere effectively for those phenomena.
content.source_6: Narrowband solar systems are wavelength‑specific and not interoperable in a single setup: an H‑alpha filter train images only H‑alpha, whereas a Ca‑K system images only Ca‑K; full‑aperture white‑light filters suppress the narrowband chromospheric signal needed for prominences.
